summary: This is an internal FBI email chain from April 2020, forwarding a November 2019 discussion about FBI agents attending a training session at the 2019 National Training Institute (NTI) in Denver. The plenary speaker was attorney Brad Edwards, who was to present on 'Jeffrey Epstein and the Rights of His Victims.' The emails discuss funding approval and contain a forwarded promotional announcement detailing Edwards's role in representing Epstein's victims and litigating violations of the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.role: Attorney for Epstein victims, Plenary Speaker
persons.context: A nationally recognized trial lawyer who represented multiple victims of Jeffrey Epstein. His presentation at the 2019 NTI centered on his experience with the case and the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Billionaire sex offender arrested in July 2019 on federal charges for sex trafficking of minors. The document references his 2008 plea deal, 2019 arrest, and subsequent death.

persons.name: Kenneth Marra
persons.context: Ruled in February 2019 that the federal government violated the rights of Epstein's victims by failing to confer with them prior to entering into the Non-Prosecution Agreement with Epstein.

persons.name: Brittany Henderson
persons.context: Mentioned as currently litigating alongside Brad Edwards to determine the remedy for the violation of the victims' rights.

persons.name: Katy Maskolunas
persons.role: Director of events and special projects
persons.context: Contact person for the National Center for Victims of Crime's National Training Institute, listed for questions about the event.

connections.description: Edwards served as an attorney for multiple victims of Jeffrey Epstein, providing legal representation and investigating the case for over a decade.
Edwards and Henderson are currently litigating together to determine the remedy for the violation of the victims' rights in the Epstein case.
Judge Marra ruled in favor of the legal argument presented by Edwards, finding the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act regarding Epstein's victims.

events.title: Epstein's Initial Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty in state court to solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution after a non-prosecution agreement with federal prosecutors, which was kept secret from victims.

events.title: Judge Marra's CVRA Ruling
events.description: US District Court Judge Kenneth Marra ruled that the federal government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by failing to confer with Epstein's victims before entering into the non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Epstein's Federal Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on federal charges for sex trafficking of minors in Florida and New York.

events.title: Closure of Criminal Case
events.description: The criminal case against Epstein was closed following his death.

events.title: 2019 National Training Institute (NTI)
events.description: A training conference held in Denver where Brad Edwards was scheduled to give a plenary presentation titled 'Jeffrey Epstein and the Rights of His Victims.'

keyFacts: Brad Edwards, an attorney for Epstein victims, was scheduled to speak at an FBI-related training conference (NTI) in December 2019 about the case and victims' rights.

The internal FBI emails show discussion and approval processes for agents to attend this training, indicating ongoing professional interest in the legal aspects of the Epstein case within law enforcement.

The promotional material details that Edwards's decade-long litigation led to a February 2019 federal court ruling that the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not consulting Epstein's victims before the 2008 non-prosecution agreement.
The document states that after Epstein's death, a hearing was held where more than a dozen victims delivered statements, which Edwards called 'a historic day for crime victims in the United States.'
The email chain is dated April 2020, forwarding discussions from November 2019, showing continued administrative activity related to the Epstein case even after his death in August 2019.
